relevants.why: Mechanical 1x with wide-range 11–46 gearing fits steep climbs; practical endurance/gravel setup relevant to tyres/gearing/bags.
Road-oriented setup with 30–34mm tyres and bag mention; useful for bag ideas but gearing/tyres not fully aligned with constraints.
Gravel setup with wide-range gearing (46/30 + 11–40) and durable tyres; well suited for wet, muddy conditions and steep climbs with a relatively lean race-oriented kit.
Reliability-focused endurance race setup with SON dynamo and Garmin charging strategy; strong reference for rain, mud, and long-distance racing.
Explicitly riding TCR with a durability-first, stripped-back setup; relevant real-world example despite heavier touring-oriented bike.
Good Garmin navigation and power strategy, but heavier loadout (Tailfin and extra kit) makes it less aligned with fast-and-light constraints.
Mechanical gravel setup with 50mm+ tyres, wide-range gearing and full bikepacking bags; excellent real-world reference for gravel vs hardtail decision in wet, muddy conditions.
Very robust, heavy full-bikepacking setup illustrating a durability-first approach, though less optimized for gravel vs hardtail comparison.
Ideal match: 32mm tyres, 2x mechanical Ultegra, Garmin navigation with backup, comfort sleep system, and direct Transcontinental experience.
Road-based Transcontinental setup with mechanical drivetrain, 32–34mm tyres, Garmin navigation, and a comfort-oriented sleep system; very relevant real-world example.
Strong endurance road setup with 32mm tyres and 2x mechanical drivetrain; suitable for mixed tarmac/gravel, though less explicit TCR context.
Matches tyre width, gearing and comfort sleep needs, but uses electronic shifting, making it a partial rather than ideal example.
Mechanical drivetrain with SON dynamo and USB charging, Garmin navigation, and a relatively lean bag setup; ideal match for fast mixed-terrain racing.
2x mechanical gearing reference with endurance context, but lacks explicit dynamo/USB power and minimal bag confirmation.
GB Duro–specific setup with Garmin navigation and no sleep system, matching a power-nap-only strategy and wet mixed-terrain racing conditions.
Mechanical 1x drivetrain with SON dynamo and USB charging, endurance all-road geometry with aerobars, and high-volume puncture-resistant tyres; excellent GB Duro–style reference.
Mechanical drivetrain with dynamo and USB charging illustrates power strategy well, but drivetrain and tyre volume are less clearly aligned with the constraints.
MTB-style setup with 50mm+ tyres designed for rough, muddy terrain; ideal hardtail/MTB reference for GB Duro conditions.
Explicit GB Duro gravel setup with wide tyres and self-sufficient power; strong gravel-side example for wet and muddy racing.
Gravel bike modified toward MTB behaviour with wide tyres and suspension stem; good hybrid comparison case.
Capable gravel setup with near-wide tyres, but less extreme than ideal GB Duro mud-focused examples.
Race-optimized gravel setup with fast 50mm+ tyres, wide MTB-style gearing and robust components suited to chunky gravel and washboard conditions.
Robust, wide-gearing setup with fast XC-style tyres that balances speed and reliability, though slightly more touring-oriented.
GB Duro–specific and durable, but heavier and more comfort-focused than ideal for a pure racing setup.
Rigid, wide-tyre setup with very wide gearing, dynamo power and Garmin navigation; ideal simple and durable reference for GB Duro conditions.
Gravel-plus rigid setup with tubeless mid-wide tyres, Garmin navigation and full bikepacking kit; workable alternative to MTB-style build.
Region- and age-matched gravel setup with Garmin navigation and mid-wide tyres, though less extreme than ideal for GB Duro mud and roughness.
